content: colourwork scrunchies tools - 3 25 mm short shank needles i use a 3 0 mm in my left hand so stitches fly off easily 16 inch 40 cm cable - fingering weight yarn in n number of colours depending on pattern i prefer cotton yarn for my hair - hairtie for the core of the scrunchie the seamless ones in black work best - stitch marker for the start of round - locking stitch markers for scrunchie construction - crochet hook 2 5 mm or 3 0 mm or yarn needle for constructing the scrunchie gauge 31 stitches in 10 cm row gauge isn t really important i m also a fairly snug knitter and for a scrunchie i d want it to be pretty solid a note on stranded colourwork and colour dominance there are a few good videos on youtube video 1 and video 2 discussing this but the general rule of thumb is dominant colour on the left your dominant colour is up to you but i usually go for the stripe in a windowpane pattern or the middle colour in a gingham pattern to make it easier i knit continental for my dominant colour and english for my background colour you can certainly do double continental but if you refuse to try continental stacy from verypinkknits demos how she does double english colorwork in this video which i think looks so cool when she gets into a groove a note on jogless colourwork there is a technique you can use to prevent a jog in the first stitch of every new row i followed this fair isle video and have found it works for me this technique is more important in the candy stripe pattern or any other more complicated ones you find there are a couple other ways to prevent a jog so feel free to do what works for you a note on a crocheted edge vs stitched edge there are two different ways to construct the completed scrunchie the crocheted edge gives a nice coloured edge that is noticeable and you can have a lot of fun with it including using a totally different colour a stitched edge is invisible and subtle which you can use for creating a seamless pattern patterns page 5 onwards lists a few simple colourwork patterns with the chart 1 dianna truong version 1b july 2025 instructions 1 cast on x number of stitches for patterns that repeat every 3 stitches i usually do 139 138 stitches +1 for patterns that repeat every 4 stitches i do either 137 136 stitches + 1 or 141 140 stitches +1 feel free to adjust this according to your gauge or yarn you choose more stitches lead to a more ruffly scrunchie which isn t always good my pink and green checkered one on page 5 is an example of one i don t use often due to it being too bulky 2 join with a
